description: From Middle English malencolie, from Old French melancolie, from Ancient Greek μελαγχολία (melankholía, “atrabiliousness”), from μέλας (mélas), μελαν- (melan-, “black, dark, murky”) + χολή (kholḗ, “bile”). Compare the Latin ātra bīlis (“black bile”). The adjectival use is a Middle English innovation, perhaps influenced by the suffixes -y, -ly.

adjectives.description: melancholy (comparative more melancholy, superlative most melancholy)

entries.meaning: (literary) Affected with great sadness or depression.
(historical) Black bile, formerly thought to be one of the four "cardinal humours" of animal bodies.
examples: Melancholy, cold and dry, thick, black, and sour, […] is a bridle to the other two hot humours, blood and choler, preserving them in the blood, and nourishing the bones.

entries.meaning: Great sadness or depression, especially of a thoughtful or introspective nature.
examples: As to Ernest... He is quite as nervously broken down as I am but it manifests itself in different ways. His inclination is towards megalomania and mine towards melancholy.
